A is a data structure consisting of a series of adjacent parenthesized elements. For example,
(a)(b)(c)
is a containing three elements, a, b, and c.
The -specific primitives are located in the chaos/preprocessor/seq subdirectory.

In C (prior to C99) and C++, cannot contain elements with any arity other than unary. However, they can contain nested or other data structures that contain multiple elements. For example, the following is a of :
((a, b))((c, d))((e, f))

In C99, can contain elements of any arity. A whose elements all have the same arity can be treated as a normal . An example of such a is
(a, b)(c, d)(e, f)
When algorithms that operate on (or specifically) invoke user-defined operations, those user-defined operations may be designed to handle the constant arity of the elements of the particular data structure being processed. For example,
#define MACRO(s, x, y, _) [x + y]
(( MACRO, (a, b)(p, q)(x, y), ~ )) // [a + b][p + q][x + y]
However, a whose elements have varying arities is called a . For example,
( int )( std::pair<int, int> )( double )
of this form must be handled specially in algorithms that invoke user-defined operations. For each -specific algorithm that invokes user-defined operations, there is an equivalent algorithm in the chaos/preprocessor/seq/variadic subdirectory that is designed to operate on . These algorithms all invoke user-defined operations with the entire element wrapped in parentheses. For example,
#define MACRO(s, type, _) type
(( MACRO, (int)(std::pair<int, int>)(double), ~ )) // int std::pair<int, int> double

section.id: Using Sequences as Generic Data Structures
section.para:
can be used as if the header is included. For example,
#define OP(s, x, _) _ ## x
(( OP, () (x)(y)(z), _ )) // _xyz
If are to be used as , on the other hand, the header should be included. For example,
#define OP(s, x, _) (_, x)
(( OP, () (a)(b, c)(d, e, f), _ )) // _abcdef

In C (prior to C99) and C++, there is no such thing as a nil . However, the special value () can be used to indicate a nil to the core operations defined in --thus allowing the generic algorithms to operate on nil in a temporal fashion. The other -specific primitives, on the other hand, do not recognize (). Therefore, a "would-be" nil result from a -specific primitive is undefined. For example,
(2, (a)(b)(c)) // (c) (3, (a)(b)(c)) // undefined
The result of generic algorithm that yields a nil is well-defined provided that it is used only as a --meaning that it can be passed to other generic algorithms, etc.--or used by the core operations in after the type prefix is stripped. For example,
( (3, () (a)(b)(c)), () (x)(y) ) // () (x)(y)
In C99, nil are well-defined as "nothing", which is accepted as the representation of nil by all primitives.
